awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An Examination of Behavioral and Biological Change in an Extended Chronological Context
awd_abstract_narration:
Drs. Jackson Njau of the Indiana University, Bloomington and Lindsay McHenry of University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, along with colleagues from the US, Europe, and Tanzania, seek to understand the relationships between Earth system history and human ("hominin") evolution by investigating the environmental contexts in which early ancestors of humans evolved. Previous researchers have postulated that climate-driven environmental changes on the African continent strongly influenced such evolution over the last several million years. Whether (and how) humans and other species adapt to changing climate is a scientific subject that has captivated public interest. Archaeology is well placed to link climate and environmental history to hominin records by integrating paleoenvironmental datasets archived in the sediments of ancient lakes near paleoanthropological sites. In addition to generating new scientific data, this project will open new interdisciplinary research frontiers across the earth sciences and anthropology that will impact the scientific debates on human origins research. 

The team will investigate how and when climate and environmental forces influenced adaptation during the critical times of human evolution. Do changes in morphology, innovation, sociality, and behavioral traits reflect changes in the local ecology, such as habitat, food, predation pressure, and the availability of resources on the landscape? These questions will be addressed by linking the detailed paleoclimatic record recovered from drilled sediment cores to excavated archeological sites. Four recently acquired cores from the ancient lake at Olduvai Gorge, Tanzania, covering over 2 million years of sedimentation, will be compared to key nearby archeological layers that document records of evolving hominin species and changes in stone tool technologies. Lake sediments archive climate history through time, therefore providing an unprecedented paleoclimatic record of the paleoanthropological material from the prehistoric Olduvai lake basin. These paleoenvironmental data will inform models of hominin land use behaviors and elucidate how climatic change drove hominin adaptations in morphology and cultural behaviors that allowed them to better adapt to variable environmental conditions. Using the composition of volcanic ash layers and detailed examination of the sedimentary units preserved in both cores and outcrops, the team will examine whether times of significant environmental change (as determined in the cores) correspond to times of significant cultural or biological change (in the outcrops and excavations). This project will provide research opportunities and training to a diverse group of American and Tanzanian scholars, provide educational outreach opportunities, and foster international collaboration and understanding.

por.por_cntn:
Few scientific subjects fascinate the public interest as much as climate and human evolution. Understanding this relationship requires interdisciplinary approaches across the Earth sciences, anthropology, and archaeology. For more than a century, scientists have speculated about why and how early humans evolved and what conditions drove transformation biological, cultural, and adaptive behavioral characteristics. More recently, climate driven environmental forces, and tectonic and orbital forcing have been hypothesized as primary drivers of human development. The premise of this idea is that the key evolutionary transitions in early humans in Africa such as speciation, innovation and migration were associated with climate and environmental change during the late Cenozoic. Paleoenvironmental proxies of marine and lacustrine sediments indicate global climatic shifts at time intervals that appear to coincide with the key evolutionary milestones in the history of human such as bipedalism, invention of technology, enlarged brain size, sociality, and migration.  

The objective of this project was to address these questions and transform the scientific debate through multidisciplinary research efforts. The research focused on Olduvai Gorge, Tanzania, a world?s renowned archaeological site that was made famous by Drs. Louis and Mary Leakey for their astonishing discoveries of early fossil humans. The site provides remarkable evolutionary sequence that document the transition of Homo habilis to Homo erectus (~1.7 Ma), the last appearances of Paranthropus boisei (~1.0 Ma) and H. erectus (~0.5 Ma), and potentially the first appearance of prehistoric H. sapiens behaviors. Our multiproxy analysis of the lacustrine sediment samples obtained from the drill core and archaeological excavations provided detailed paleoenvironmental profile and high-resolution chronostratigraphy that has radically revised the history of the Olduvai basin and associated paleoanthropological record. We extend the Olduvai record perhaps back to ~2.5 Ma by revealing a new stratigraphy (nearly 500 kyr older than the deepest strata exposed on the outcrop) that was inconceivable in the past nearly hundred years of research there (Fig. 1). 

We discovered that the paleolake basin is much older and contained a more permanent, extensive, and deeper lake than previously thought (Fig. 2). This project developed a new paleogeographic model of the paleolake and establish a new chronostratigraphic framework upon which detailed paleoclimatic and paleoenvironmental records can be gauged, interpreted, and correlated, providing context for the hominin evolutionary sequence at high-resolution. The organic geochemical record supports our paleoenvironmental reconstruction, and documents abrupt transitions in terrestrial vegetation, aquatic biota, and lake dynamics on a Milankovitch and sub-Milankovitch scale, which potentially exerted complex influences on hominin-exploited paleolandscapes. Additionally, the revised dates of Masek (0.82 Ma) suggests that the last appearance of H. erectus at Olduvai was about 320 kyr earlier than previously thought. Similarly, the new dates of lower Ndutu Beds (0.5 Ma) substantially extendthe antiquity of archaic Homo sapiens in the basin. 

Broader impact: This project has opened a new frontier of interdisciplinary research in paleoanthropology, geology, geophysics, geochronology, tephra geochemistry, isotope geochemistry and paleobiology, and provided important career building to American, African, and European scientists and students. The project provided training opportunity to numerous graduate students who collected primary data for their dissertations and made positive impact on the development of local capacity and palaeoanthropological infrastructure in Tanzania. We have engaged local community in the project by involving local people in the field research through collaborations in various synergies including conservation and protection of paleoanthropological resources, sites, and onsite museums.
